sent1: "It was a little bit embarrassing the way we played in the first two games," Thomas said.
sent2: "We're in the Stanley Cup finals, and it was a little bit embarrassing the way we played in the first two games.
annotation1: Correct  missing the attribution....but these cases seem borderline...
annotation2: Thomas said -> 0; 0 -> We're in the Stanley Cup finals;

sent1: The commission estimated California lost $937 million to corporate tax shelters in 2001.
sent2: California's lost tax revenue was mostly due to international corporate tax shelters.
annotation1: Correct  To me this is borderline correct.  We dont have the part about the commission estimating the loss.  but generally the meaning that it lost tax revenue to corp. tax shelters seems about the same.  some minor numerical deletions from s1 to s2.
annotation2: A has more details; arguably not a paraphrase;

sent1: Board Chancellor Robert Bennett declined to comment on personnel matters Tuesday.
sent2: Mr. Mills declined to comment yesterday, saying that he never discussed personnel matters.
annotation1: Incorrect  Not sure how this is annotated as a paraphrase!  Robert Bennett != Mr. Mills
annotation2: *not a paraphrase; different names;

sent1: The three grocery chains were relying on store managers and replacement workers to keep their stores open.
sent2: The supermarket chains have used managers and replacement workers to keep their stores open, often at reduced hours.
annotation1: Incorreect  Seems semantically equivalent to me, save for the added information, but seems superfluous
annotation2: *should be a paraphrase; 0 -> often at reduced hours;

sent1: "We put a lot of effort and energy into improving our patching process, probably later than we should have and now we're just gaining incredible speed.
sent2: "We've put a lot of effort and energy into improving our patching progress, probably later than we should have.
annotation1: Correct  Borderline - additional information makes this sentence seem cause and effect - like it is set up for that second clause.
annotation2: A contains more than B; and now we're just gaining incredible speed -> 0;

sent1: Benchmark Treasury 10-year notes gained 17/32, yielding 4.015 percent.
sent2: The benchmark 10-year note was recently down 17/32, to yield 4.067 percent.
annotation1: Correct  Meaning difference - s1 goes up, s2 goes down.  And numbers are off.
annotation2: gained -> was ... down (opposite meaning);

sent1: Pacific Northwest has more than 800 employees, and Wells Fargo has 2,400 in Washington.
sent2: It has 800 employees, compared with Wells Fargo's 2,400.
annotation1: Correct  Due to anaphora (it) - which MT systems won't get right.
annotation2: anaphoric reference;

sent1: Every Thursday, a grains management committee meets in the Commission's agriculture directorate to decide the outcome of a weekly export tender.
sent2: A grains management committee normally meets each Thursday in the Commission's agriculture unit -- another target of Wednesday's raids -- to decide the outcome of a weekly export tender.
annotation1: Incorrect  This really should be marked as a paraphrase, just some crazy alternations.  Seems like the only difference is "another target of Wednesday's raids" but is that really changing the meaning that much?  OK re-reading this, I don't know, this seems borderline in the semantic equivelance case - not sure if this is really changing the meaning a whole lot.
annotation2: A contains more than B; another target of Wednesday's raids -> 0;

sent1: Several thousand 3rd Infantry troops, including the 3rd Brigade Combat Team based at Fort Benning in Columbus, began returning last week.
sent2: A few thousand troops, most from the division's 3rd Brigade Combat Team based at Fort Benning in Columbus, began returning last week, with flights continuing through Friday.
annotation1: Incorrect  Seems semantically equivalent to me, save for the added information, but seems superfluous
annotation2: B contains more information than A; Several -> a few; 0 -> with flights continuing through Friday;

sent1: Kodak expects earnings of 5 cents to 25 cents a share in the quarter.
sent2: Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected Kodak to earn 68 cents a share for the quarter.
annotation1: Correct / Incorrect (generic tag reduction)  Under MSRP guidelines with the generic tags reduced, this is correct.  But system doesnt have reduction so it marks at as not a paraphrase, which would also be correct.
annotation2: not a paraphrase; B contains more information; numbers do not match;

sent1: Dewhurst's proposal calls for an abrupt end to the controversial "Robin Hood" plan for school finance.
sent2: The committee would propose a replacement for the "Robin Hood" school finance system.
annotation1: Incorrect  s1 has Dewhurst (one person), while s2 has a committee.  s1 says the proposal calls for an end to the plan while s2 proposes a replacement - that's semantically different to me.
annotation2: Dewhurst's proposal > 0; calls for an abrupt end to -> would propose a replacement for;

sent1: Added Mr. Prodi: "Maybe, but the old age helps us to understand our strengths and our weakness."
sent2: "Maybe, but the old age helps us to understand our strength and our weakness and the reality of the world.
annotation1: Correct  I guess if we call removing the attribution as changing the meaning, then yes MSRP is correct, though the underlying statement is semantically equivalent.
annotation2: Added Mr. Prodi -> 0; 0 -> and the reality of the world;

sent1: Police said the suspected Marriott suicide bomber was Asmar Latin Sani, 28, from the island of Sumatra.
sent2: A sibling also identified Sani, 28, who was from the island of Sumatra, police said.
annotation1: Correct  No mention about the suicide bomber.  System thinks it is a paraphase because of enough other words and phrases outside the "suspected Marriott suicide bomber" --- actualyl I am surprised that this is marked as paraphrase by the system, the sentences are kind of short.
annotation2: not a paraphrase; the suspected Marriott suicide bomber -> 0;

sent1: Bulger's brother is now on the agency's ''10 Most Wanted'' list, sought in connection with 21 murders.
sent2: Bulger's brother, a former FBI informant, is now on the law enforcement agency's "10 Most Wanted" list.
annotation1: Incorrect  I think the general gist of s1 and s2 are the same, the other information doesn't change things all that much?
annotation2: A and B each have extra material; sought in connection with 21 murders -> 0; 0 -> a former FBI informant;

sent1: The Food and Drug Administration rejected ImClone's 2001 application to sell Erbitux, citing shoddy research.
sent2: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration rejected ImClone's original application in December 2001, saying the trial had been sloppily conducted.
annotation1: Correct  surprised system doesn't get this, but shoddy research probably is hard to match with trial sloppily conducted (tough paraphrase)
annotation2: not a paraphrase; shoddy research  != the trial had been sloppily conducted;

sent1: To put it very simply, Antetonitrus is Brontosaurus's older brother, hence the name.
sent2: Antetonitrus was brontosaurus' older brother, hence the name.
annotation1: Correct  Not sure why system gets this wrong.
annotation2: A has intro. adverbial; To put it very simply, -> 0;

sent1: Police believe Wilson shot Reynolds, then her mother once in the head before fatally turning the gun on herself.
sent2: Police believe Wilson then shot Jennie Mae Robinson once in the head before turning the gun on herself.
annotation1: Correct  s1 is about Reynolds + plus, s2 is only about the mom, so different facts represented.  I think system gets it right because there is so much word overlap...infact just Reynolds and then JMR are different.
annotation2: different names; Reynolds -> Jennie Mae Robinson;

sent1: Stocks dipped lower Tuesday as investors opted to cash in profits from Monday's big rally despite a trio of reports suggesting modest improvement in the economy.
sent2: Wall Street moved tentatively higher Tuesday as investors weighed a trio of reports showing modest economic improvement against an urge to cash in profits from Monday's big rally.
annotation1: Correct  Lot of words in common but there is that difference between "dipped lower" and "moved tentatively higher" - semantic difference
annotation2: *not a paraphrase (opposite in meaning); Stocks dipped lower -> Wall Street moved tentatively higher;

sent1: "If we could do that throughout the world, we could end terrorism," he said.
sent2: This is a hospital that treats everybody as people, and if we could do that throughout the world, we could end terrorism."
annotation1: Correct  Anaphora. I think s1's "that" refers to the first part of s2 but in a different sentence.  So yeah a paraphrase, but hard for a system to get right which looks as much overlapping material as possible.
annotation2: was judged a paraphrase by their anaphora criterion; 0 -> This is a hospital that treats everybody as people;

sent1: While waiting for a bomb squad to arrive, the bomb exploded, killing Wells.
sent2: The bomb exploded while authorities waited for a bomb squad to arrive.
annotation1: Correct  missing key part - Killing Wells.  Lot of material the same.
annotation2: probably should be judged a paraphrase by overlap criterion; killing Wells -> 0; short sentence;

sent1: The bodies of some of the dead, pulled out from under the train, were laid out beside the tracks while emergency services brought in wooden coffins.
sent2: The bodies of many of the dead, pulled from under the partially derailed train, were laid out by the tracks awaiting identification.
annotation1: Correct  Lot of overlap in the first 2/3, but s1 is about wooden coffins, s2 is abou waiting identification.
annotation2: emergency services brought in wooden coffins -> 0; 0 -> awaiting identification;

sent1: Stripping out the extraordinary items, fourth-quarter earnings were 64 cents a share compared to 25 cents a share in the prior year.
sent2: Earnings were 59 cents a share for the three months ended May 25 compared with 15 cents a share a year earlier.
annotation1: Correct  System was way off!  Not sure how it got this wrong.  Maybe small 3-gram sequences were enough to call it paraphrase?
annotation2: numbers do not match;

sent1: The House voted 425 to 2 to clear the bill, the first of 13 that Congress must pass each year to fund the federal government.
sent2: The bill is among the first of 13 that Congress must pass each year to fund the federal government.
annotation1: Incorrect  Information is the same - first of 13, Congrass pass, fund federal government.  The original sentence simply has the voting numbers.
annotation2: A entails B; The House voted 425 to 2 to clear the bill -> 0;

sent1: A tropical storm rapidly developed in the Gulf of Mexico Sunday and was expected to hit somewhere along the Texas or Louisiana coasts by Monday night.
sent2: A tropical storm rapidly developed in the Gulf of Mexico on Sunday and could have hurricane-force winds when it hits land somewhere along the Louisiana coast Monday night.
annotation1: Correct  The meaning is slightly different - first sentence is about where the storm hits, the second one seems more about the caliber of the storm.
annotation2: B has more information than A; 0 -> could have hurricane-force winds;

sent1: Lacy's last column, filed from the hospital, appeared in Friday's editions.
sent2: Lacy's last column appeared in Friday's edition of The Afro.
annotation1: I don't know!  The system marks this as a paraphrase because of last column, appeared, friday, etc. But s1 has "filed from the hospital and editions" and s2 has "The Afro"
annotation2: short sentence; filed from the hospital -> 0;

sent1: The victim, whose name was not released, underwent surgery at the hospital.
sent2: The wounded doctor, whose name was withheld, underwent surgery at the hospital for three gunshot wounds.
annotation1: Borderline / Correct  This is an anaphora issue...is the victim = the wounded doctor?  oterwise, the facts of name being withheld and undergoing surgery at the hospital are all the same except for three gunshot wounds.
annotation2: anaphoric reference; 0 -> three gunshot wounds;

sent1: The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average .DJI added 38 points, or 0.42 percent, to 9,165.
sent2: The Dow Jones Industrial Average [$INDU] ended at session highs, gaining 64.64 points, or 0.7 percent, to 9,191.09.
annotation1: Incorrect (generic tag redution)  I don't think this is a paraphrase because s2 has a session high which s1 does not have.  Numbers are all off so system will not mark this as a paraphrase, which I think is correct.
annotation2: not a paraphrase; numbers do not match;

sent1: The military said it had killed 12 rebels and captured nine in the campaign so far, for the loss of six soldiers wounded.
sent2: The military said it had killed 16 rebels and captured nine in the campaign so far, with one soldier killed and six wounded.
annotation1: Correct  I am not sure why this is marked as not para byt the humans if the numbers are xx'd out.  But maybe the "old soldier killed" makes a difference?  System thinks it is a paraohrase - there is a ton in common.
annotation2: numbers differ; 0 -> with one soldier killed;

sent1: Richard Miller remained hospitalized after undergoing a liver transplant, but his wife has recovered.
sent2: Richard Miller, 57, survived a lifesaving liver transplant but remains hospitalized.
annotation1: Correct  Not sure about this one, but I feel this additional information - "his wife has recovered" is a bit heavier than additional information like dates or ages. ???
annotation2: A has more information; remained hospitalized -> survived; but his wife has recovered -> 0;

sent1: Expenses are expected to be approximately $2.3 billion, at the high end of the previous expectation of $2.2-to-$2.3 billion.
sent2: Spending on research and development is expected to be $4.4 billion for the year, compared with the previous expectation of $4.3 billion.
annotation1: Correct / Incorrect (generic tag reduction)  MSRP annotation is "correct" given the guidelines to ignore numbers.  But when numbers are included, the system says incorrect, which is right.
annotation2: not a paraphrase; numbers are different; expenses -> Spending on research and development;

sent1: Critics say the law violates civil liberties, something House Judiciary Committee Chairman James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., says he is sensitive to.
sent2: House Judiciary Committee Chairman James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis., says he is sensitive to civil liberties complaints.
annotation1: Correct  s1 is about Sensenbrenner agreeing with critics, s2 is saying what he is sensitive to.  It's subtle but I think different enough.  A lot of the material is overlapping so system gets it wrong, tough.
annotation2: A contains more than B; Critics say the law violates civil liberties;

sent1: Gyorgy Heizler, head of the local disaster unit, said the coach had been carrying 38 passengers.
sent2: The head of the local disaster unit, Gyorgy Heizler, said the coach driver had failed to heed red stop lights.
annotation1: Correct  s1 is about specifying the number of passengers, s2 is about why the accident happened.  System sees the first half and then coach and that probably is enough overlap to push it over the edge.  The non-overlapping part makes all the difference in the semantics.
annotation2: carrying 38 passengers -> 0; 0 -> failed to heed red stop lights;

sent1: Get it all out," says Howard Davidowitz, chairman of Davidowitz & Associates, a national retail consulting firm based in New York City.
sent2: Innocent or not, "she's damaged goods," said Howard Davidowitz, chairman of Davidowitz & Associates, a national retail consulting firm in New York.
annotation1: Correct  quotes by Davidowitz are different.  But material describing his background dominate the sentence and system thinks it is a paraphrase.
annotation2: *not a paraphrase; quoted material is different;

sent1: The three men have pleaded not guilty and their lawyers have asked the High Court to dismiss the charges, saying the state has failed to present a solid case.
sent2: Defense lawyers asked the High Court to dismiss the charges, saying the state has failed to present a solid case.
annotation1: Correct  subtle - there is a lot of text in common, but that remaining but is subsumption
annotation2: A contains more information; The three men have pleaded not guilty -> 0;

sent1: "Americans don't cut and run, we have to see this misadventure through," she said.
sent2: She also pledged to bring peace to Iraq: "Americans don't cut and run, we have to see this misadventure through."
annotation1: Correct  important information issue with "pledged to bring peace to iraq"
annotation2: B contains more than A; She also pledged to bring peace to Iraq: -> 0

sent1: Ultimately, she will earn more than the $900,000 that Kenny Perry got for winning the PGA Tour event.
sent2: But she'll earn more than the $900000 (about R7.5-million) Kenny Perry got for winning.
annotation1: Correct  Not sure why system doesn't get this - inclusion of too much other material like R7.5mil and PGA tour event?  But this material doesn't change the meaning.
annotation2: the PGA Tour event -> 0; 0 -> (about R7.5-million);

sent1: "I had no direct interest and Craxi begged me to intervene because he believed the operation damaged the state," he told a packed courtroom during a 45-minute address.
sent2: "I had no direct interest, and Craxi begged me to intervene because he believed that the operation damaged the state," Mr. Berlusconi said.
annotation1: Incorrect  Anaphora with Berlusconi, and 45min address is superfluous.  Everything else is almost exactly the same.  System gets it right
annotation2: A contains extra material about place and time; a packed courtroom during a 45-minute address -> 0;

sent1: In two weeks, he'll probably send out Peace Rules in the Preakness.
sent2: Frankel said Peace Rules will run in the Preakness Stakes on May 17.
annotation1: Incorrect?  Not sure about this one, I think this requires lots of world knowledge to get right.  But there is a difference between sending out peace rules and sayign he will run.
annotation2: in two weeks -> on May 17; send out -> will run (requires general knowledge);

sent1: The CGT warned of prolonged industrial action unless Raffarin agreed.
sent2: The large CGT union warned France of lengthy industrial action.
annotation1: Correct  Missing semantic difference of unless Raffarin agreed.  Everything else pretty much the same so it trips up system.
annotation2: short sentence; unless Raffarin agreed -> 0; 0 -> warned France;

sent1: Last year, he made an unsuccessful bid for the Democratic nomination for governor.
sent2: He ran last year for the Democratic nomination for Texas governor, but lost the primary to multimillionaire Tony Sanchez.
annotation1: Correct  ?  Not sure if the Tony Sanchez information difference should make this semantically different, I guess the main point that he lost last year is maintained.  System doesn't call it paraphrase because
annotation2: B contains more than A; 0 -> but lost the primary to multimillionaire Tony Sanchez;

sent1: Lowe's, with about half as many stores, reported a 33 percent increase in third-quarter profit behind a 12 percent jump in same-store sales.
sent2: Home Depot reported a 22 percent jump in third-quarter profit behind a nearly 8 percent rise in same-store sales.
annotation1: Correct  Numbers AND store are wrong, but general template is the same - tripping up system.
annotation2: names are different; Lowe's -> Home Depot; numbers do not match; with about half as many stores -> 0;

sent1: The daily Hurriyet said the raid aimed to foil a Turkish plot to kill an unnamed senior Iraqi official in Kirkuk.
sent2: The daily Hurriyet said the raid aimed to foil a Turkish plot to kill an unnamed senior Iraqi Kurdish official in Kirkuk, but Gul has denied any Turkish plot.
annotation1: Correct  s2 adds additional information (Causality)
annotation2: B subsumes A; 0 -> but Gul has denied any Turkish plot

sent1: He said the FDA was hoping Congress and the courts would bring clarity to the situation and some financial relief to consumers.
sent2: He said FDA hopes Congress and the courts will bring clarity to the situation and some financial relief to consumers - perhaps before the 2004 elections.
annotation1: Correct  I guess the date sort of makes it different?  But for the most part, the sentences are matched almost exactly save for that extra phrase.
annotation2: B contains more than A; 0 -> perhaps before the 2004 elections;

sent1: Of 24 million phoned-in votes, 50.28 percent were for Studdard, putting him 130,000 votes ahead of Aiken.
sent2: Of the 24 million phone votes cast, Studdard was only 130,000 votes ahead of Aiken.
annotation1: Incorrect  This seems borderline to me.  The content is the same, but not sure if the 50.28% is enough of a difference to knock it to non-paraphrase as originally annotated.
annotation2: arguably a paraphrase; A contains more than B; 50.28 percent -> 0;

sent1: This is America, my friends, and it should not happen here," he said to loud applause.
sent2: "This is America, my friends, and it should not happen here."
annotation1: Incorrect?  Missing the attribution?
annotation2: an exact copy of a quotation; he said to loud applause -> 0;

sent1: State Democratic Chairman Herman Farrell, who is also chairman of the state Assembly's Ways and Means Committee, seemed perfectly happy to make it a political fight.
sent2: State Democratic Chairman Herman Farrell, who is also chairman of the Assembly's Ways and Means Committee, supports the Legislature's budget plan.
annotation1: Correct  Yeah there is enough intention difference here: perfectly happy to make it a political fight vs. supports Legislature's budget plan.  I think the programs get tripped up because there is such strong direct overlap in the first 66% of the sentence.
annotation2: seemed perfectly happy to make it a political fight -> 0; 0 -> supports the Legislature's budget plan;

sent1: Thirty-three of the 42 men had been arrested by Wednesday evening, said Daniel Bogden, U.S. attorney in Nevada.
sent2: Thirty-four of the men have been arrested and the others are being sought, US Attorney Daniel Bogden said yesterday.
annotation1: Correct  number of men are different, date is missing and others being sought are missing.  There are a lot of fragment overlaps, but subtle differences change the meaning.
annotation2: 33 -> 34; 42 -> 0; minor differences;

sent1: Hilsenrath was also indicted on 33 counts of wire fraud, which each carry a maximum penalty of five years in prison, a $250,000 fine and restitution.
sent2: Each of those counts carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine plus restitution.
annotation1: Correct  Yeah these are not semantically equivalent, I agree with annotation.  That first part is just not captured and actually makes a difference in the meaning I think, this one is tough for a system given all the other subsumption things it has to deal with.
annotation2: A contains more than B; Hilsenrath was also indicted on 33 counts of wire fraud -> 0;

sent1: The valid signatures of 897,158 registered California voters must be collected and turned in to county election officials by Sept. 2.
sent2: To force a recall election of Davis, the valid signatures of 897,158 registered California voters must be turned in to election officials.
annotation1: Incorrect  The date hasn't made a difference in other sentences, I feel this is really splitting hairs.
annotation2: B contains more information than A;  0 -> To force a recall election of Davis;

sent1: The Coast Guard airlifted the survivors to Bartlett Regional Hospital, Wetherell said.
sent2: Soon after, a Coast Guard helicopter landed and took the men to Bartlett Regional Hospital, Mills said.
annotation1: Incorrect  This could be correct but the survivors --> men is a sort of tough inference for a system to make.  But the attribution is off...Wetherell is replaced by Mills.
annotation2: airlifted -> helicopter landed and took; different names;

sent1: And of those, 149, or 55%, "claimed to treat, prevent, diagnose or cure specific diseases."
sent2: And of those, 55 percent, or 149, claimed to treat, prevent, diagnose or cure specific diseases -- despite the regulations prohibiting that kind of statement.
annotation1: Correct  this is borderline for me, but I guess that second clause changes the semantics enough.  How come the MT metrics like this?  This is a lot of new material that is added to the sentence.
annotation2: B contains information not in A; 0 -> despite the regulations prohibiting that kind of statement;

sent1: Several states and the federal government later passed similar or more strict bans.
sent2: Following California's lead, several states and the federal government passed similar or tougher bans.
annotation1: Incorrect  Not sure why this is marked as not a paraphrase, seems ok with me.  Does California make that big of a difference?  Maybe this is the casaulity thing.
annotation2: arguably a paraphrase; 0 -> Following California's lead;

sent1: I'm never going to forget this day.
sent2: I am never going to forget this throughout my life."
annotation1: Incorrect  s2 doesn't have what should be forgotten.
annotation2: short sentence; 0 -> throughout my life;

sent1: The security official's backup couldn't fill in because he was on active military duty, Strutt said.
sent2: The security official's backup was on active duty, and the lottery association didn't have a replacement in New Jersey, Strutt said.
annotation1: Incorrect  This is like the Liza Minelli example on p.12 - some minor information added, but still counts as a paraphrase.  The information added here is the lottery association, which I bet could be found in another sentence in the original sentence's context.
annotation2: B has more information than A; 0 -> and the lottery association didn't have a replacement in New Jersey;

sent1: These are real crimes that hurt a lot of people.
sent2: "These are real crimes that disrupt the lives of real people," Smith said.
annotation1: Incorrect  This is an annotation inconsistency - in other examples if the attribution was not included, it would be marked as NotPara by the humans.  I guess the quote is more or less a paraphrase, though "hurt a lot of people" and "disrupt lives..." may be a tough para for a sytsem to get.
annotation2: very short sentence; B contains more information than A; 0 -> Smith said;

sent1: The other semifinal between Guillermo Coria of Argentina and Martin Verkerk of the Netherlands is also compelling.
sent2: The other, much less likely semifinal will match seventh-seeded Guillermo Coria of Argentina against the unseeded Dutchman Martin Verkerk.
annotation1: Correct  chunks of first sentence are correct, but the other part changes things (is also compelling vs. much less likely semifinal)...
annotation2: between -> will match; is also compelling -> 0; B has more detail in the description of the individuals (named entity recognition could help);

sent1: The broad Standard & Poor's 500 Index .SPX gained 22.25 points, or 2.23 percent, to 1,018.22, based on the latest available figures.
sent2: The broad Standard & Poor's 500 Index .SPX gained 11.22 points, or 1.13 percent, at 1,007.19.
annotation1: Depends (Correct) - difference between annotation and system analysis   If you remove all the numbers, then yeah these are direct paraphrases.  But the system doesn't do that and so sees a big difference, which is the correct thing to do.  Under the MSRP annotation guidelines these are paraphrases, but if numbers were not xxx'd out, then it wouldn't be a paraphrase.
annotation2: not a paraphrase; numbers do not match;

sent1: Aiken's study appears in the Sept. 24 issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.
sent2: The findings appear in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association.
annotation1: Correct  System gets this wrong because this requires a lot of inference:  Aiken;s study --> findings Sep 24 issue --> Wed issue
annotation2: anaphoric reference;

sent1: "The integration is exceeding almost every expectation we set for ourselves," Mr Roberts said on Thursday.
sent2: It's manageable, and the integration is exceeding "almost every expectation we set for ourselves."
annotation1: Correct  I guess if we call removing the attribution as changing the meaning, then yes MSRP is correct, though the underlying statement is semantically equivalent.
annotation2: A contains the speaker and time; matching quotations;

sent1: He urged Congress to "send me the final bill as soon as possible so that I can sign it into law."
sent2: "I urge Congress to quickly resolve any differences and send me the final bill as soon as possible so that I can sign it into law," he said.
annotation1: Incorrect  I think this is pretty much the same thing.  The resolve differences phrase shouldnt make that much of a difference.  System will mark as a paraphrase because a majority of the text is the same.
annotation2: arguably a paraphrase; 0 -> quickly resolve any differences;

sent1: They certainly reveal a very close relationship between Boeing and senior Washington officials.
sent2: The e-mails reveal the close relationship between Boeing and the Air Force.
annotation1: CORRECT  anaphora: they --> emails named entity: Washington officials --> Air Force
annotation2: A is more specific; anaphoric reference; senior Washington officials -> the Air Force;

sent1: The leading actress nod went to energetic newcomer Marissa Jaret Winokur as Edna's daughter Tracy.
sent2: Marissa Jaret Winokur, as Tracy, won for best actress in a musical.
annotation1: Correct  Lots of difficult transformations for a system.  "leading actress nod" --> "won for best actress"  for example.
annotation2: leading actress nod went to -> won for best actress in a musical;

sent1: Tennessee Titans quarterback Steve McNair apologized Thursday for his arrest hours earlier in Nashville on suspicion of drunken driving and illegal possession of a handgun.
sent2: Tennessee Titans quarterback Steve McNair was arrested Thursday and charged with drunken driving and possession of a handgun.
annotation1: Correct  One is about the apology, the other is about the act.  Lot of words in overlap, but subtle difference that may be hard for a system to get.
annotation2: apologized for -> 0; A entails B;

sent1: Federal and local officials, including Bush, saw no apparent sign of terrorism.
sent2: Federal officials earlier said there is no evidence of terrorism.
annotation1: Correct  Some minor differences: "local officials" is dropped and "including Bush" is dropped.  So the original sentence subsumes the second.
annotation2: short sentence; including Bush -> 0; no apparent sign -> no evidence;

sent1: Security experts are warning that a new mass-mailing worm is spreading widely across the Internet, sometimes posing as e-mail from the Microsoft founder.
sent2: A new worm has been spreading rapidly across the Internet, sometimes pretending to be an e-mail from Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates, antivirus vendors said Monday.
annotation1: Correct  Lots of transformations - inclusion of security experts, mass-mailing, widely --> rapidly, pretending --> posing, founder --> Bill Gates.  security-experts --> antivirus vendors.  probably all these transformations nudge the classifier from calling this paraphrase.
annotation2: Security experts -> antivirus vendors (requires world knowledge); posing as -> pretending to be; word order;

sent1: Others keep records sealed for as little as five years or as much as 30.
sent2: Some states make them available immediately; others keep them sealed for as much as 30 years.
annotation1: Borderline...but I guess incorrect since who knows if others = states (though the anaphora issue was waived for other examples I saw).  But little as five years vs. immediately is a big difference.  Much of the sentences are similar except for these few words so I can see how the system can call it paraphrase
annotation2: as little as five years -> 0; 0 -> make them available immediately;

sent1: Scrimshaw, Supervisor, Best Minister and Ten Most Wanted are expected to complete the Belmont field.
sent2: Best Minister, Scrimshaw, and Ten Most Wanted all had workouts on Monday morning.
annotation1: Correct  s1 is about who will be competing and s2 is about the fact they had workouts.  The sentences are short so the names in the first half push things over the edge for the system?

sent1: "Tomorrow at the Mission Inn, I have the opportunity to congratulate the governor-elect of the great state of California.
sent2: "I have the opportunity to congratulate the governor-elect of the great state of California, and I'm looking forward to it."
annotation1: Borderline  I could go either way on this one - correct or incorrect.  I can see how a system would call this a paraphrase since 2/3 of the sentence is almost exactly the same.
annotation2: Tomorrow at the Mission Inn -> 0; 0 -> and I'm looking forward to it;

sent1: Prosecutors did an about-face in May and asked that the autopsy reports be unsealed after portions of Conner Peterson's autopsy report favorable to the defense were leaked to the media.
sent2: They asked that the autopsy reports be unsealed after portions of the autopsy report on Peterson's unborn son that were favorable to the defense were leaked to the media.
annotation1: Not sure  I guess the differene is the about-face part in the beginning?  Everything else is really the same...
annotation2: anaphoric reference; did an about-face in May -> 0; Conner Peterson -> Peterson's unborn son;

sent1: The other 24 members are split between representatives of the securities industry and so-called "public" board members.
sent2: Of the 24 directors who are not exchange executives, half are representatives of the securities industry and half are designated public members.
annotation1: Correct  Difficult transformations with half and split.
annotation2: split between -> half are ... and half are; who are not exchange executives -> 0;

sent1: The women said those rape victims who did come forward were routinely punished for minor infractions while their assailants escaped judgement, prompting most victims to remain silent.
sent2: The women said victims of rape who came forward routinely were punished for minor infractions while their assailants escaped judgment.
annotation1: Correct  s2 misses the causality part...it's like the first part sets up the second.  Too much material overlap otherwise.
annotation2: B contains less than A; prompting most victims to remain silent -> 0;

sent1: In recent years, Hampton kept in touch with friends and stayed in trouble: He faced charges of fare-beating and credit card theft.
sent2: In recent years, Mr. Hampton continued to run into trouble, facing charges of fare-beating and credit-card theft.
annotation1: Incorrect  I think kept in touch with friends isn't that big of a deal, unless it is implied that these friends kept him in trouble, but would really need the context to figure this out.  I think under the circumstances it's ok for the system to mark this as a paraphrase.
annotation2: kept in touch with friends -> 0;

sent1: Besides Hampton and Newport News, the grant funds water testing in Yorktown, King George County, Norfolk and Virginia Beach.
sent2: The grant also funds beach testing in King George County, Norfolk and Virginia Beach.
annotation1: Correct  I am guessing there is a difference between water testing (s1) and beach testing (s2).  System thinks this is a paraphrase because last half is basically the same save for that one water --> beach transformation.
annotation2: probably should be judged a paraphrase by overlap criterion; Besides Hampton and Newport News -> 0;

sent1: "Our strong preference is to achieve a financial restructuring out of court, and we remain hopeful we can do so," chief executive Marce Fuller said.
sent2: "Our strong preference is to achieve a financial restructuring out of court," Mirant CEO Marce Fuller said in a prepared statement early Friday.
annotation1: Incorrect  These seem pretty similar - main part of the quote is exactly the same, attribution is the same, conjunction of "and we remain hopeful we can do so" doesn't change much for me.
annotation2: matching quotations; and we remain hopeful we can do so -> 0; 0 -> in a prepared statement early Friday;

sent1: Police using pepper spray arrested 12 people Monday night at a march and rally by about 400 activists protesting an annual training seminar of the Law Enforcement Intelligence Unit.
sent2: Police used pepper spray and rubber bullets to disperse a downtown march and rally last night by activists protesting an annual police intelligence-training seminar.
annotation1: Correct  Meaning difference - this is subtle for a machien to get - s1 seems to be more about the arresting of 12 people, while s2 is about the dispersing of the crowd.  Talking about the same event but different spins on it.  So a lot of the words are of course overlapping, but not semantically equivalent.
annotation2: A contains more details;

sent1: Penn Traffic's stock closed at 36 cents per share on Wednesday on Nasdaq, up two cents.
sent2: Penn Traffic stock closed Wednesday at 36 cents, up 2 cents, or 6.2 percent, from Tuesday's close.
annotation1: Incorrect  Numbers are all right and dates are all right but the system marks this as a paraphrase which I think is totally fine.  Not sure why humans marked this as not a paraphase
annotation2: probably a paraphrase; 0 -> or 6.2 percent, from Tuesday's close;

sent1: During the hearing, Morales expressed "sincere regrets and remorse" for his actions.
sent2: Morales, who pleaded guilty in July, expressed "sincere regret and remorse" for his crimes.
annotation1: Incorrect  Information differences don't seem to really change semantic content.
annotation2: B contains more than A; 0 -> who pleaded guilty in July;

sent1: The report forecasts there will be 71,079 hot spots worldwide this year, up from just 14,752 in 2002 and 1,214 in 2001.
sent2: The report also claims that there will be up to 9.3 million visitors to hot spots this year, up again from the meagre 2.5 million in 2002.
annotation1: Correct  Not sure why system gets this as a paraphrase, the number are all off, though the basic sentence template is pretty similar.
annotation2: the numbers differ; and 1,214 in 2001 -> 0;

sent1: The Episcopal Diocese of Central Florida became one of the first in the nation Saturday to officially reject the national denomination's policies on homosexuality.
sent2: The Episcopal Diocese of Central Florida voted Saturday to repudiate a decision by the denomination's national convention to confirm a gay man as bishop.
annotation1: Incorrect  I think s1 is more general than s2's specific repudiation claim.  I think system is right to call this non-para.
annotation2: one of the first in the nation -> 0; officially reject -> vote to repudiate; policies homosexuality -> a gay man as bishop (requires general knowledge);

sent1: Russian stocks fell after the arrest last Saturday of Mikhail Khodorkovsky, chief executive of Yukos Oil, on charges of fraud and tax evasion.
sent2: The weekend arrest of Russia's richest man, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, chief executive of oil major YUKOS, on charges of fraud and tax evasion unnerved financial markets.
annotation1: Incorrect?  I think we could easily find examples where inference would link fragments like "russian stocks fell" to "unnerved financial markets".  I think the system marking this as a paraphrase is fine.
annotation2: arguably a paraphrase; Russian stocks fell after -> unnerved financial markets;

sent1: Ohio Attorney General Jim Petro hailed the appellate court ruling.
sent2: Ohio Attorney General Jim Petro was pleased by the ruling, spokesman Mark Gribben said.
annotation1: Correct ??  Again the attribution difference is ignored.  have to inference that the ac ruling in s1 is the ruling in s2.
annotation2: hailed -> was pleased by; appellate court -> 0; 0 -> spokesman Mark Gribben said;

sent1: Anything less is unacceptable," said Gordon, the ranking Democrat on the House Space and Aeronautics subcommittee.
sent2: Gordon is the senior Democrat on the House Subcommittee on Space and Aeronautics.
annotation1: Correct  System is way off here.   The gist of s1 is what Gordon said, which isn't in s2 "Anything less is unacceptable"   But there is a majority of other material there that is highly overlapped to overrule the four words not in s2.
annotation2: B is missing a quotation; Anything less is unacceptable," said Gordon -> 0;

sent1: Wal-Mart estimates more than 100 million Americans visit their stores every week.
sent2: Each week 138 million shoppers visit Wal-Mart's 4,750 stores.
annotation1: Correct  Tough inference and sentence transformation.  more than 100mil ~ 138 mil for example.
annotation2: not a paraphrase; Americans -> shoppers; numbers do not match;

sent1: The work appears in the Oct. 22/29 issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.
sent2: The study appears in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association (news - web sites).
annotation1: Correct (reduced number issue)  I guess Oct 22/29 --> wed is reduced for the humans, but not for the system.
annotation2: work -> study; Oct. 22/29 issue -> Wednesday's;

sent1: On May 1, he crawled through a narrow, winding canyon, rappelled down a 60-foot cliff and walked some six miles down the canyon.
sent2: He crawled through a narrow, winding canyon, rappelled down a 60-foot cliff, and walked some six miles down the canyon near Canyonlands National Park in southeastern Utah.
annotation1: Incorrect  I feel this is a paraphrase: throw out the date and the exact location and everything is exactly the same.
annotation2: arguably a paraphrase; B contains more detailed description; 0 -> near Canyonlands National Park in southeastern Utah;

sent1: "In so many different ways, the artistry of black musicians has conveyed the experience of black Americans throughout our history," Bush said.
sent2: Surrounded by singers from Harlem, Bush said: ''The artistry of black musicians has conveyed the experience of black Americans throughout our history.
annotation1: Incorrect  I think this is ok, the other information doesn't add so much...
annotation2: probably should be considered paraphrase; In so many different ways -> 0; 0 -> Surrounded by singers from Harlem

sent1: The new analysis found that 32 of the 16,608 participants developed ovarian cancer during about 5 years of follow-up.
sent2: The new analysis found that 32 of 16,608 participants developed ovarian cancer in about 5 1/2 years of follow-up, including 20 women taking hormones.
annotation1: Incorrect  Subsumption - s2 adds 20 women taking hormones, but that doesn't change the meaning too much for me....well could go either way.  gray area.
annotation2: B has more information than A; 0 -> including 20 women taking hormones;

sent1: Both are being held in the Armstrong County Jail.
sent2: Tatar was being held without bail in Armstrong County Prison today.
annotation1: Correct  Surprised that the system gets this right.  I guess the sentences are so short and "<be> being held in Armstrong Country Jail/Prison" outweighs the other changes?
annotation2: very short sentence; Both -> Tatar; 0 -> without bail;

sent1: The Herald reported on Tuesday that internet developer Bruce Simpson was building a missile from parts ordered over the internet and shipped through Customs.
sent2: A home handyman is building a missile in his garage with parts bought over the internet and shipped through Customs.
annotation1: Correct  The first half does not overlap, need inferencing to tie them together.
annotation2: *not a paraphrase; internet developer Bruce Simpson -> A home handyman;

sent1: The women said victims of rape who came forward routinely were punished for minor infractions while their assailants escaped judgment.
sent2: The women said victims of rape who came forward were routinely punished for minor infractions while their attackers escaped judgment, prompting most victims to remain silent.
annotation1: Correct  There seems to be this casaulty effect with s2's additional phrase, whcih s1 does not ahve.  System calls it paraphrase because 80% of this long sentence overlaps strongly.  So subtle meaning difference?
annotation2: B contains more than A; prompting most victims to remain silent; [I've seen this sentence pair before]

sent1: Navistar shares were down 44 cents, or 1.1 percent, at $41.19 on the New York Stock Exchange after falling as low as $39.93.
sent2: Navistar shares rose a penny to $41.64 at late afternoon on the New York Stock Exchange after earlier falling as low as $39.93.
annotation1: Correct  Not sure why we get this wrong, a bunch of the numbers are off.  But maybe enough is in common to push it over the edge.
annotation2: numbers do not match; were down != rose;

sent1: Lawmakers at the closed-door hearing focused on the National Intelligence Estimate reports on Iraq's chemical, biological and nuclear weapons programs.
sent2: Lawmakers on the House panel will question intelligence analysts at the closed-door hearing about the factors that went into compiling the National Intelligence Estimate reports on Iraq's weapons programs.
annotation1: Incorrect  I feel these two are semantically different.  s1 focuses on stating what the lawmakers focus on.  s2 says specifically that they will question what they are focusing on.  Maybe I am splitting hairs too much on this.
annotation2: on the House panel will question intelligence analysts -> 0; chemical, biological and nuclear -> 0;

sent1: The supercomputer is actually an eServer and storage system with a peak speed of 7.3 trillion calculations per second.
sent2: It's a cluster of 44 IBM servers with a peak speed of 7.3 trillion calculations per second.
annotation1: Correct  Anaphora - inferencing between "supercomputer...storage system" --> it  . This one is wicked hard for a system and requires massive amounts of world knowledge.
annotation2: anaphoric reference; an eServer and storage system -> a cluster of 44 IBM servers;

sent1: The launch marks the start of a new golden age in Mars exploration.
sent2: The launch marks the start of a race to find life on another planet.
annotation1: Incorrect  I feel this should not be a paraphrase, a new golden age for Mars is a bit different from find life on another planet, I think there is some majoring inferencing going on.
annotation2: not a paraphrase; new golden age in Mars exploration -> race to find life on another planet;

sent1: "It would be completely irresponsible to reverse course and kill country-of-origin labeling," said Daschle.
sent2: "It would be completely irresponsible to reverse course," said Senate Democratic Leader Tom Daschle, of South Dakota.
annotation1: Incorrect  extra information doesn't change meaning.  i think the system is right.
annotation2: named entity recongition could match name in A to name + description in B; and kill country-of-origin labeling -> 0;

sent1: Site Finder has been visited 65 million times since its introduction, Galvin said.
sent2: Through Sunday, Sept. 21, Site Finder has been visited over 65 million times by Internet users.
annotation1: Correct  Hard inference - have to know that the introduction = Sunday, Sep 21.  That's really hard for a system.
annotation2: Galvin said -> 0; since its introduction -> since Sept. 21;

sent1: The case comes out of Illinois and involves a for-profit company called Telemarketing Associates Inc.
sent2: The case decided Monday centered around an Illinois fund-raiser, Telemarketing Associates.
annotation1: Correct  I guess this is a paraphrase, the gist is that there is a case which involves an Illinois company called Telemarketing Associates so the different information in s1 and s2 doesn't really change that.  This is problematic for a system since the only things in common are a few words - case, TA, Illinois....
annotation2: comes out of -> 0; for-profit company -> fund-raiser;

sent1: Licensing revenue slid 21 percent, however, to $107.6 million.
sent2: License sales, a key measure of demand, fell 21 percent to $107.6 million.
annotation1: Correct  Not sure why system does not get this right.  Though numbers are matched, slid and fell are in different places and a key measure of demand is in the middle which s1 doesn't have.
annotation2: B contains material not in A; 0 -> a key measure of demand;

sent1: Mr Pollard said: "This is a terrible personal tragedy and a shocking blow for James's family.
sent2: Nick Pollard, the head of Sky News said: "This is a shocking blow for James's family.
annotation1: Incorrect  Subsumption - there is the missing material of "terrible personal tragedy" in s2, but for me, removing this doesn't change the overall semantics.
annotation2: named entity recognition might help; 0 -> the head of Sky News; a terrible personal tragedy -> 0;

sent1: Higher courts have ruled that the tablets broke the constitutional separation of church and state.
sent2: The federal courts have ruled that the monument violates the constitutional ban against state-established religion.
annotation1: Correct  Lots of transformations   higher courts --> federal courts tablets broke --> monument violates separation --> ban church/state --> state-established religion
annotation2: tablets -> monument; broke ... separation of church and state -> violates ban against state-established religion;
